name: FileSystemEntity
comment:
The common super class for dart-io.File, dart-io.Directory, and dart-io.Link objects.

dart-io.FileSystemEntity objects are returned from directory listing operations. To determine if a FileSystemEntity is a dart-io.File, a dart-io.Directory, or a dart-io.Link perform a type check:

if (entity is File) (entity as File).readAsStringSync();

You can also use the dart-io.FileSystemEntity.type or dart-io.FileSystemEntity.typeSync methods to determine the type of a file system object.

Most methods in this class occur in synchronous and asynchronous pairs, for example, dart-io.FileSystemEntity.exists and dart-io.FileSystemEntity.existsSync. Unless you have a specific reason for using the synchronous version of a method, prefer the asynchronous version to avoid blocking your program.

Here's the exists method in action:

entity.exists().then((isThere) {
  isThere ? print('exists') : print('non-existent');
});

Other resources

Dart by Example provides additional task-oriented code samples that show how to use various API from the dart-io.Directory class and the dart-io.File class, both subclasses of FileSystemEntity.

  • I/O for Command-Line Apps a section from A Tour of the Dart Libraries covers files and directories.

  • Write Command-Line Apps, a tutorial about writing command-line apps, includes information about files and directories.

isAbsolute.name: isAbsolute
isAbsolute.comment:
Returns a dart-core.bool indicating whether this object's path is absolute.

On Windows, a path is absolute if it starts with \\ or a drive letter between a and z (upper or lower case) followed by :\ or :/. On non-Windows, a path is absolute if it starts with /.

absolute.name: absolute
absolute.comment:
Returns a dart-io.FileSystemEntity whose path is the absolute path to this. The type of the returned instance is the type of this.

The absolute path is computed by prefixing a relative path with the current working directory, and returning an absolute path unchanged.

isWatchSupported.name: isWatchSupported
isWatchSupported.comment:
Test if dart-io.FileSystemEntity.watch is supported on the current system.

Mac OS 10.6 and below is not supported.

parent.name: parent
parent.comment: The directory containing this. If this is a root directory, returns this.

exists.name: exists
exists.comment:
Checks whether the file system entity with this path exists. Returns a Future<bool> that completes with the result.

Since FileSystemEntity is abstract, every FileSystemEntity object is actually an instance of one of the subclasses dart-io.File, dart-io.Directory, and dart-io.Link. Calling dart-io.FileSystemEntity.exists on an instance of one of these subclasses checks whether the object exists in the file system object exists and is of the correct type (file, directory, or link). To check whether a path points to an object on the file system, regardless of the object's type, use the dart-io.FileSystemEntity.type static method.

existsSync.name: existsSync
existsSync.comment:
Synchronously checks whether the file system entity with this path exists.

Since FileSystemEntity is abstract, every FileSystemEntity object is actually an instance of one of the subclasses dart-io.File, dart-io.Directory, and dart-io.Link. Calling dart-io.FileSystemEntity.existsSync on an instance of one of these subclasses checks whether the object exists in the file system object exists and is of the correct type (file, directory, or link). To check whether a path points to an object on the file system, regardless of the object's type, use the dart-io.FileSystemEntity.typeSync static method.

rename.name: rename
rename.comment:
Renames this file system entity. Returns a Future<FileSystemEntity> that completes with a dart-io.FileSystemEntity instance for the renamed file system entity.

If dart-io.FileSystemEntity.rename.newPath identifies an existing entity of the same type, that entity is replaced. If dart-io.FileSystemEntity.rename.newPath identifies an existing entity of a different type, the operation fails and the future completes with an exception.

renameSync.name: renameSync
renameSync.comment:
Synchronously renames this file system entity. Returns a dart-io.FileSystemEntity instance for the renamed entity.

If dart-io.FileSystemEntity.renameSync.newPath identifies an existing entity of the same type, that entity is replaced. If dart-io.FileSystemEntity.renameSync.newPath identifies an existing entity of a different type, the operation fails and an exception is thrown.

resolveSymbolicLinks.name: resolveSymbolicLinks
resolveSymbolicLinks.comment:
Resolves the path of a file system object relative to the current working directory, resolving all symbolic links on the path and resolving all '..' and '.' path segments. dart-io.FileSystemEntity.resolveSymbolicLinks returns a Future<String>

dart-io.FileSystemEntity.resolveSymbolicLinks uses the operating system's native filesystem api to resolve the path, using the realpath function on linux and Mac OS, and the GetFinalPathNameByHandle function on Windows. If the path does not point to an existing file system object, dart-io.FileSystemEntity.resolveSymbolicLinks completes the returned Future with an FileSystemException.

On Windows, symbolic links are resolved to their target before applying a '..' that follows, and on other platforms, the '..' is applied to the symbolic link without resolving it. The second behavior can be emulated on Windows by processing any '..' segments before calling dart-io.FileSystemEntity.resolveSymbolicLinks. One way of doing this is with the URI class: :new Uri.parse('.').resolveUri(new Uri.file(input)).toFilePath();, since resolve removes '..' segments.

resolveSymbolicLinksSync.name: resolveSymbolicLinksSync
resolveSymbolicLinksSync.comment:
Resolves the path of a file system object relative to the current working directory, resolving all symbolic links on the path and resolving all '..' and '.' path segments.

dart-io.FileSystemEntity.resolveSymbolicLinksSync uses the operating system's native filesystem api to resolve the path, using the realpath function on linux and Mac OS, and the GetFinalPathNameByHandle function on Windows. If the path does not point to an existing file system object, dart-io.FileSystemEntity.resolveSymbolicLinksSync throws a FileSystemException.

On Windows, symbolic links are resolved to their target before applying a '..' that follows, and on other platforms, the '..' is applied to the symbolic link without resolving it. The second behavior can be emulated on Windows by processing any '..' segments before calling dart-io.FileSystemEntity.resolveSymbolicLinks. One way of doing this is with the URI class: :new Uri.parse('.').resolveUri(new Uri.file(input)).toFilePath();, since resolve removes '..' segments.

stat.name: stat
stat.comment:
Calls the operating system's stat() function on the dart-io.FileSystemEntity.path of this dart-io.FileSystemEntity. Identical to FileStat.stat(this.path).

Returns a Future<FileStat> object containing the data returned by stat().

If the call fails, completes the future with a dart-io.FileStat object with .type set to FileSystemEntityType.NOT_FOUND and the other fields invalid.

statSync.name: statSync
statSync.comment:
Synchronously calls the operating system's stat() function on the dart-io.FileSystemEntity.path of this dart-io.FileSystemEntity. Identical to FileStat.statSync(this.path).

Returns a dart-io.FileStat object containing the data returned by stat().

If the call fails, returns a dart-io.FileStat object with .type set to FileSystemEntityType.NOT_FOUND and the other fields invalid.

delete.name: delete
delete.comment:
Deletes this dart-io.FileSystemEntity.

If the dart-io.FileSystemEntity is a directory, and if dart-io.FileSystemEntity.delete.recursive is false, the directory must be empty. Otherwise, if dart-io.FileSystemEntity.delete.recursive is true, the directory and all sub-directories and files in the directories are deleted. Links are not followed when deleting recursively. Only the link is deleted, not its target.

If dart-io.FileSystemEntity.delete.recursive is true, the dart-io.FileSystemEntity is deleted even if the type of the dart-io.FileSystemEntity doesn't match the content of the file system. This behavior allows dart-io.FileSystemEntity.delete to be used to unconditionally delete any file system object.

Returns a Future<FileSystemEntity> that completes with this dart-io.FileSystemEntity when the deletion is done. If the dart-io.FileSystemEntity cannot be deleted, the future completes with an exception.

deleteSync.name: deleteSync
deleteSync.comment:
Synchronously deletes this dart-io.FileSystemEntity.

If the dart-io.FileSystemEntity is a directory, and if dart-io.FileSystemEntity.deleteSync.recursive is false, the directory must be empty. Otherwise, if dart-io.FileSystemEntity.deleteSync.recursive is true, the directory and all sub-directories and files in the directories are deleted. Links are not followed when deleting recursively. Only the link is deleted, not its target.

If dart-io.FileSystemEntity.deleteSync.recursive is true, the dart-io.FileSystemEntity is deleted even if the type of the dart-io.FileSystemEntity doesn't match the content of the file system. This behavior allows dart-io.FileSystemEntity.deleteSync to be used to unconditionally delete any file system object.

Throws an exception if the dart-io.FileSystemEntity cannot be deleted.

watch.name: watch
watch.comment:
Start watching the dart-io.FileSystemEntity for changes.

The implementation uses platform-dependent event-based APIs for receiving file-system notifications, thus behavior depends on the platform.

  • Windows: Uses ReadDirectoryChangesW. The implementation only supports watching directories. Recursive watching is supported.

  • Linux: Uses inotify. The implementation supports watching both files and directories. Recursive watching is not supported. Note: When watching files directly, delete events might not happen as expected.

  • Mac OS: Uses FSEvents. The implementation supports watching both files and directories. Recursive watching is supported.

The system will start listening for events once the returned dart-async.Stream is being listened to, not when the call to dart-io.FileSystemEntity.watch is issued.

The returned value is an endless broadcast dart-async.Stream, that only stops when one of the following happends:

  • The dart-async.Stream is canceled, e.g. by calling cancel on the dart-async.StreamSubscription.

  • The dart-io.FileSystemEntity being watches, is deleted.

Use events to specify what events to listen for. The constants in dart-io.FileSystemEvent can be or'ed together to mix events. Default is dart-io.FileSystemEvent.ALL.

identical.name: identical
identical.comment:
Checks whether two paths refer to the same object in the file system. Returns a Future<bool> that completes with the result.

Comparing a link to its target returns false, as does comparing two links that point to the same target. To check the target of a link, use Link.target explicitly to fetch it. Directory links appearing inside a path are followed, though, to find the file system object.

Completes the returned Future with an error if one of the paths points to an object that does not exist.

identicalSync.name: identicalSync
identicalSync.comment:
Synchronously checks whether two paths refer to the same object in the file system.

Comparing a link to its target returns false, as does comparing two links that point to the same target. To check the target of a link, use Link.target explicitly to fetch it. Directory links appearing inside a path are followed, though, to find the file system object.

Throws an error if one of the paths points to an object that does not exist.

type.name: type
type.comment:
Finds the type of file system object that a path points to. Returns a Future<FileSystemEntityType> that completes with the result.

dart-io.FileSystemEntityType has the constant instances FILE, DIRECTORY, LINK, and NOTFOUND. dart-io.FileSystemEntity.type will return LINK only if the optional named argument dart-io.FileSystemEntity.type.followLinks is false, and dart-io.FileSystemEntity.type.path points to a link. If the path does not point to a file system object, or any other error occurs in looking up the path, NOTFOUND is returned. The only error or exception that may be put on the returned future is ArgumentError, caused by passing the wrong type of arguments to the function.

typeSync.name: typeSync
typeSync.comment:
Synchronously finds the type of file system object that a path points to. Returns a dart-io.FileSystemEntityType.

dart-io.FileSystemEntityType has the constant instances FILE, DIRECTORY, LINK, and NOTFOUND. dart-io.FileSystemEntity.type will return LINK only if the optional named argument dart-io.FileSystemEntity.typeSync.followLinks is false, and dart-io.FileSystemEntity.typeSync.path points to a link. If the path does not point to a file system object, or any other error occurs in looking up the path, NOTFOUND is returned. The only error or exception that may be thrown is ArgumentError, caused by passing the wrong type of arguments to the function.

isLink.name: isLink
isLink.comment: Checks if type(path, followLinks: false) returns FileSystemEntityType.LINK.

isLinkSync.name: isLinkSync
isLinkSync.comment: Synchronously checks if typeSync(path, followLinks: false) returns FileSystemEntityType.LINK.

parentOf.name: parentOf
parentOf.comment: Removes the final path component of a path, using the platform's path separator to split the path. Will not remove the root component of a Windows path, like "C:\" or "\\server_name\". Ignores trailing path separators, and leaves no trailing path separators.

hashCode.name: hashCode
hashCode.comment:
Get a hash code for this object.

All objects have hash codes. Hash codes are guaranteed to be the same for objects that are equal when compared using the equality operator ==. Other than that there are no guarantees about the hash codes. They will not be consistent between runs and there are no distribution guarantees.

If a subclass overrides dart-io.FileSystemEntity.hashCode it should override the equality operator as well to maintain consistency.

runtimeType.name: runtimeType
runtimeType.comment: A representation of the runtime type of the object.

==.comment:
The equality operator.

The default behavior for all dart-core.Objects is to return true if and only if this and dart-io.FileSystemEntity.==.other are the same object.

Override this method to specify a different equality relation on a class. The overriding method must still be an equivalence relation. That is, it must be:

  • Total: It must return a boolean for all arguments. It should never throw or return null.

  • Reflexive: For all objects o, o == o must be true.

  • Symmetric: For all objects o1 and o2, o1 == o2 and o2 == o1 must either both be true, or both be false.

  • Transitive: For all objects o1, o2, and o3, if o1 == o2 and o2 == o3 are true, then o1 == o3 must be true.

The method should also be consistent over time, so equality of two objects should not change over time, or at least only change if one of the objects was modified.

If a subclass overrides the equality operator it should override the dart-io.FileSystemEntity.hashCode method as well to maintain consistency.

toString.name: toString
toString.comment: Returns a string representation of this object.

noSuchMethod.name: noSuchMethod
noSuchMethod.comment:
dart-io.FileSystemEntity.noSuchMethod is invoked when users invoke a non-existent method on an object. The name of the method and the arguments of the invocation are passed to dart-io.FileSystemEntity.noSuchMethod in an dart-core.Invocation. If dart-io.FileSystemEntity.noSuchMethod returns a value, that value becomes the result of the original invocation.

The default behavior of dart-io.FileSystemEntity.noSuchMethod is to throw a dart-core.NoSuchMethodError.
